title: Here’s who will be on the ballot for November’s 2025 City Council election
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: The preliminary election reduced City Council candidates before the general election on November 4, narrowing the field for voters.
At-large city councilor Ruthzee Louijeune led with 17.65% of votes; total eight at-large candidates move forward.
District 1 incumbent Gabriela Coletta Zapata led with 76.96% of votes, while challenger McDuffie-Stanziani had 14.56%.

title: Mayoral preliminary: Wu maintains huge lead over Kraft as both advance to November election
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu advances to Boston's November election, leading with over 45 percentage points in preliminary results.
Josh Kraft proceeds to the general election despite losing to Wu; he plans to campaign 'harder, louder, and stronger.'
Preliminary election turnout was nearly 18% with over 75,000 ballots cast; 2017 saw a 27.8% turnout.

title: What to know about the viral surrogacy lawsuit
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Cindy Bi, a San Francisco venture capitalist, sued surrogate Rebecca Smith after a miscarriage, accusing her of causing the loss.
Bi reportedly harassed Smith online, causing Smith to change jobs and relocate due to fears from online threats.
Surrogacy industry is expanding rapidly, with challenges such as non-disclosure of potential pregnancy risks by intended parents.

title: A healthy Hampus Lindholm could change Bruins’ fortunes in several areas
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Hampus Lindholm is returning to Bruins' training camp with a clean bill of health after missing 65 games last season.
Lindholm, 31, aims to anchor Boston's defense and improve their power play, which ranked 29th in the NHL.
Despite past injuries, Lindholm remains optimistic about Boston's chances, emphasizing confidence in the team's roster and potential.

title: Drake Maye receives a ringing endorsement from Bills QB Josh Allen
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bills QB Josh Allen praises Patriots QB Drake Maye, calling him an 'unbelievable kid' and a promising talent.
Drake Maye and Josh Allen are set to face off in Weeks 5 and 15 of the NFL season.
Maye completed 30-of-46 passes for 287 yards, one touchdown, and one interception in the Patriots' season-opening loss.

title: MBTA debuts train design to honor historic New England railroad, with more on the way
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: MBTA introduces a vintage maroon and yellow train honoring the historic Boston and Maine Railroad to the Commuter Rail.
By year-end, additional trains honoring New Haven and New York Central Railroads will enter service, says the MBTA.
The refurbished trains offer modern upgrades including remote diagnostics, cameras, and new brake systems, reports MBTA.

title: Patriots could be facing off against their former 1st-round pick in Miami
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots' former first-round pick Cole Strange signs with Miami Dolphins off Cleveland Browns' practice squad.
Strange played 29 games over three seasons with the Patriots before being released due to injuries and ineffectiveness.
Miami Dolphins need Strange after starting right guard James Daniels suffered a pectoral injury in Week 1.

title: Tufts to go tuition-free for families making less than $150K
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Tufts University will offer free tuition to undergraduates from families with incomes below $150,000 starting next fall.
Families earning less than $60,000 will receive financial aid packages that exclude student loans, Tufts officials announced.
Tufts joins other New England universities in waiving tuition for students based on family income levels.

title: Aunt now caring for young daughter of parents killed in Watertown murder-suicide
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: David Minasvand, 31, shot and killed Karine Asatryan, 35, and Nadia Abrahamian, 80, in Watertown before taking his own life.
The couple's 1-year-old daughter, Madeline, will be cared for by her aunt following the incident, according to a fundraiser.
Over $37,000 has been raised to support Madeline's upbringing, including medical care, childcare, and future education costs.

title: What Don Sweeney said about the Bruins’ playoff odds, timeline for new captain
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Don Sweeney expects the Bruins to be more competitive this season, emphasizing staying healthy and having strong team standards.
Sweeney mentioned potential roles for young players like Fraser Minten and Matt Poitras, highlighting competition for roster spots.
The Bruins will start the season without a set captain, allowing a natural leader to emerge as the season progresses.
